When commenting this line, the problem goes away. But I don't have nested categories so I would imagine it would go away.

item.title: Ticket #1508 (permalink clash postname and post_id) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
We might have to just list what rewrite structures we're going to accept and which ones we won't (or can't, without making the code extremely complex.)

Reminder to self: create checkboxes of common, supported rewrite structures on Options => Permalinks and call the user-supplied permalink structure box "Custom (Advanced User s Only)" with a link to a Codex page discussing which structures will work and which won't.

item.title: Ticket #1257 (Pingbacks sent from wrong URI for posts first published in advanced ...) updated
item.dc:creator: bennettmcelwee
item.description: The cause of this problem is the cache mechanism used in get_post(). I created the ​FixBack WordPress plugin to fix this problem, but of course a core change would be more elegant. See ​WordPress pingback and trackback bug for full details.

item.title: Ticket #1538 (Trailing slash on RSS feed URL generates a spurious blank line in XML ...) created
item.dc:creator: Frobenius
item.description:
When generating RSS feeds and using permalinks, the url to the RSS feed includes a trailing slash. When the url contains a trailing slash, row 1 of the RSS XML generated by WordPress contains a blank line. This causes the RSS feed to fail validation. Here is an example:

​http://www.valenceband.com/wp/feed/ ...generates a blank line on row 1. ​http://www.valenceband.com/wp/feed ...does not generate a blank line.

The url without permalinks works perfectly, of course:

​http://www.valenceband.com/wp/?feed=rss2

I have only tested this with 1.5.1.3.

Why does the trailing slash generate a blank line in the RSS feed XML? It works the same with any theme and with plug-ins deactivated. Perhaps the get_feed_link function in template-functions-links.php could be modified to generate a url without the trailing slash when using permalinks.

item.title: Ticket #1537 ("Remember Me" box on login should be unchecked by default) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith

item.title: Ticket #1537 ("Remember Me" box on login should be unchecked by default) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
The "Remember Me" checkbox added in ​changeset 2733 defaults to being checked.

This does away with most of the benefit of the "Remember Me" checkbox.

If someone wants to be remembered on a computer that is secure and the default is "unchecked," it only requires a one-time action. They check the box onces and are done with it. People who use WordPress from insecure locations don't have to do anything, and they never worry that their blog will be compromised.

If, however, the default is "checked," every time that someone wants to log in from an insecure computer, they have to remember to uncheck that box. If they forget, their blog could be compromised. From a security and a usability standpoint, it makes much more sense for the box to be unchecked by default.
